pageContext.claim: “In Germany, Denmark, Norway,  Sweden and many other countries, SCHOOLS ARE OPEN WITH NO PROBLEMS. The Dems think it would be bad for them politically if U.S. schools open before the November Election, but is important for the children & families. May cut off funding if not open!”
pageContext.analysis: Trump is wrong to make this comparison. Germany, Denmark and Norway have also made significant progress in reducing covid-19 infections while Sweden never closed its schools or shut down its economy (and had soaring infections that Trump has criticized). Moreover, schools have reopened in Germany, Denmark and Norway with rules and procedures that have changed the school experience. German officials said that there had been big changes to the way children were educated in the country; at a typical secondary school class, half of the students attended in the morning and the other half in the afternoon, and face-to-face instruction takes place in small groups. In Denmark, classes reopened for younger children in April, but with strict regulations in place about class sizes and social distancing. Norway also instituted social distancing regulations and smaller class sizes. Some European countries are moving toward normal classes in the fall, but no country has done so with infections soaring as in the United States.
